Award.AwardTitle: HSI-DCL STEM Experiences in Research for Early Science Success

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project was submitted in response to the Dear Colleague Letter for Hispanic Serving Institutions "Stimulating Research on Effective Strategies in Undergraduate STEM Education at Two-Year Hispanic Serving Institutions," NSF15-078. It is implementing a suite of educational approaches for rising STEM majors at Miami-Dade College InterAmerican Campus in partnership with Fairchild Tropical Botanic Garden. These experiences are built around two evidence-based teaching modalities applied to introductory STEM courses and authentic 8-week research experiences in biology. The impact of this combination of approaches on improving the retention of Hispanic students in STEM fields is largely untested in a Hispanic Serving community college environment. Such colleges are particularly important to the high education of Hispanic students. The teaching modalities are Peer Led Team Learning (PLTL) and Process-oriented Guided Inquiry Learning (POGIL). The project will provide early research immersion in plant biology/environmental science alongside supportive services such as peer tutoring, faculty mentoring, science lectures, research presentations, and other activities.

The project will determine the impact of these high-impact educational approaches and redesigned science curricula to engage and motivate students to persist and achieve in STEM fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of STEM Experiences in Research for Early Science Success (STEM EXPRESS) was to advance a model for improving retention and student persistence in STEM at a two-year Hispanic-serving institution by integrating early immersion in undergraduate research with co-curricular STEM-focused activities.

The project's goal was to be met through attainment of the following objectives: 1) Increase student persistence through immersion in authentic, early research experiences 2) Increase student engagement and motivation through the use of high-impact, active learning pedagogies and redesigned introductory science courses 3) Increase student retention by building a STEM community that integrates academic and support services such as peer tutoring, faculty mentoring, and other wraparound services and 4) Develop and sustain research program/experience adapted and suitable for a two-year teaching institution.

All project objectives were achieved.

The research was the overarching component of the project and for that Miami Dade College, Eduardo J. Padron Campus (formerly InterAmerican Campus) and The Million Orchid Project at Fairchild Tropical Botanic Garden teamed up with the objective of restoring populations of endangered orchids by developing better asymbiotic orchid culture techniques. Working in an orchid research space established through the grant at MDC Padron Campus, the project examined how different nutritive supplements affected the growth characteristics of E. tampensis seedlings in vitro. Using micropropagation techniques, seedlings were transplanted into sterile containers with different media treatments. Seedlings were then placed under fluorescent grow lights. Plants were allowed to grow in the lab for over one year to enhance maturation. The final phase of the project was transplanting the young plants to the natural habitat.

Minority STEM students are considered at risk due to high drop-out rates and delayed graduation process. Additionally, the students in the grant reported that it was difficult to adapt to a system that was vastly different from what they were used to. (Students shared rare instances in which they were ridiculed or bullied for being studious at home.) The STEM EXPRESS project took advantage of the multicultural experiences of the students to build camaraderie and focus. This required the creation of interactive sessions in which students: talked about their experiences in an open setting, served as Teaching Assistants, were guided through the rigor of evaluating scientific papers, deciphered STEM fields for transfer, received guidance for applications to upper division STEM programs at well-regarded schools, and various other STEM-community building activities. All the steps were carefully glued together and monitored using intrusive advising. Students were teamed with students in a community setting. Talking openly about goals reminded each of being accountable for his/her progress.

After a couple of semesters in the program, it was evident how some students became confident about their success in the sciences and their academic potential. We noticed their interest growing as evidenced by their dedication in participating in the research and other activities in the grant. This was borne out by the high retention and academic performance rates in the program. These observations suggest our model has the potential to enhance the success of minority students in STEM. The model's facets include 1) research 2) Teaching Assistantship 3) mentorship 4) transfer.

Sixty-four college-bound, freshman, and sophomore students were enrolled over two years of the project. Students enrolled at the campus when the project was active (Summer term 2017 to Summer term 2019) recorded an average GPA of 2.86 (SD = 0.94). Of these, 32% obtained a STEM Associate's degree in an average of 2.9 years (SD = 9.4). In contrast students in the STEM EXPRESS program recorded an average GPA of 3.51 (SD = 0.46); 70% earned a STEM Associate's degree in an average of 2.33 years (SD = 1.3); 60% transferred to upper division schools in the STEM pathway; others are continuing pursuing the Associate's degree. The average time span a student was part of the project was 2.4 terms; three students were part of the project for one term or less. The program thus recorded a retention/persistence rate of 95%.

STEM EXPRESS afforded faculty training in process-oriented guided inquiry learning (POGIL), a high-impact teaching strategy. Students developed experimental scientific inquiry skills, knowledge, and science career advice on what is involved in pursuing a scientific career. More broadly, however, the research platform provided through the grant afforded extending the knowledge base and activities in biological sciences for students and the department of Natural Sciences at Miami Dade College Padron Campus. The combined impact of research immersion and co-curricular wrap-around services appeared to have a positive effect on the students' engagement, progression, and completion of their chosen STEM degree.

Although STEM EXPRESS indicates student success when co-curricular activities are integrated with early immersion in undergraduate research, additional studies need to be developed that will more clearly point out the social and psychological factors that allow STEM students to fulfill their own expectations in STEM.
